climbs.name: Squash Rocker
climbs.fa: Scott Unice, Mike Grossman, Kristen Carrol - 1990

content.description:
Start a few feet left of the stacked blocks of

Jointed Venture

and make your way up underneath the large roof by either climbing the dihedral (mellow, probably not the original route) or tackling the face straight up (hard but only way to clip the first bolt).

Plug a piece underneath the roof and make an awkward rockover move to the right to get out from under the roof. Clip the 2nd bolt and make your way up the upper slab, pinching crystals and feeling a bit runout.
content.protection:
2 bolts + a hand size cam for the roof.

Micros and small nuts useful to protect the dihedral. Long runners to avoid heinous rope drag.
content.location:
Located in between

Hippies Anonymous

and

Jointed Venture

.

Better to walk off to the east although you could sling trees at the top and lower.

content.description:
A short and very strenuous route that weighs in heavy at the grade.

Neanderthal or Not at All

climbs a steep face using rounded flakes and a few hidden edges. Appropriately named, the crux of this route may reset your vocabulary.  Limited holds and an unobvious sequence....no wonder its a classic!
content.protection:
One bolt, stoppers, and a few small cams. Build an anchor in a set of thin cracks or work left towards the bolts on

Squash Rocker

. Rap or Walk off.
content.location:
Hidden amongst the choss, this route is tucked away on the walls far right side just next to

Jointed Venture

content.description:
This is a good route to practice fiddling with gear on. Start by clambering up a few blocks using jams, smears and the occasional shallow edge. Climb through flakes following the most profound crack passing both good and marginal placements. Continue on this until the crack dies out. Slope, smear, then insecurely rock your way left onto a large ledge to gain the anchor.

This route is short and almost more work than its worth. The crux sits high and the protection is a bit hard to place. Shaky gear, mixed with insecure stances keeps this line just that, a

jointed venture

.
content.protection: All gear to a set of hangers. Stoppers, slings, and cams from .2 - #2 bd. At the time of this writing there were two quick links on a two bolt anchor allowing a rap, otherwise perform the half-heinous walk off.
content.location:
This route lies on the small crag north of

Extreme Unction

. It sits directly right of

Squash Rocker

and starts in the crack splitting the three stacked blocks.

content.description: In the ruckman's book they list the route and the FA as anonymous, I don't feel to bad about posting as hippies anonymous because I found this route due to two hippies who would load a bowl then climb 40 feet, load a bowl climb another 40 feet.....all day long.
content.protection: This is an excellent trad/sport lead, with one placement a verticle crack the other a horizontal follwed by a bolt, you can sling the tree directly above the route but I would also clip into the the anchors above bob's rocking chair.

content.description:
Pulling into the hand crack in the corner is probably the crux.  Move up under the roof and pull the lip (awkward). If you go up from here and right you can use

Squash Rockers

anchors.  dirty but fun
content.protection: Standard rack including ferg spider stick.  Goggles for your belayer who is going to be showered with dirt.

content.description:
Pitch 1

- Begin on Jointed Venture skipping the bolted belay on the ledge.  Continue up a fun, easy chimney.  At the top of the chimney climb up and left past some blocks and up to a crack.  Climb the crack until blocked by a bush and move left onto a slab.  Continue up and left and set up a belay in blocks on a good, sandy ledge.  140' (5.9)

Pitch 2

- Climb up and right using a diagonal crack which is a bit dirty.  Move up through blocks then left to a right leaning crack.  Climb up and right following the crack then a ramp to a stance below the roof.  A move leads up and left to the roof.  Traverse left under roof and then climb chimney/cracks above to the top of the formation.  90' (5.9)
content.protection:
We brought two sets of cams to #2 camalot, then 1 #3, 1 #3.5, 1 #4.  Medium to large stoppers.  I could have used one more large cam.

No bolts, pitons or other fixed gear was left.
content.location: This climbs the direct south face of Bob's Rocking Chair to the summit of the formation.  The climb begins on Jointed Venture and finishes a few feet left of "Bob's Rocking Chair" block at the top of the formation.
